title: 108_hr3569
content: The National Film Preservation Act of 2003 reauthorizes and amends the National Film Preservation Board. It is also known as Title I of the Act. The National Film Preservation Act of 2003 amends the duties of the Librarian of Congress regarding film preservation, including coordination with other collection and preservation activities. The National Film Preservation Act of 1992 tasks the Librarian of Congress with activities to make films more accessible, review and update the national film preservation plan, and expand initiatives for preserving the moving image heritage of the United States. The National Film Preservation Act of 1992 empowers the National Film Preservation Board to oversee the preservation of various moving image formats in the United States, including film, videotape, and television. Amendments to the Act include increasing the number of board members and providing reimbursement for travel expenses. The National Film Preservation Act of 1996 amends the responsibilities of the National Film Preservation Board, including the review and approval of special projects and the utilization of the National Audio-Visual Conservation Center for storing preserved films in the National Film Registry. The National Film Preservation Act of 1996 ensures that films in the National Film Registry are properly stored and made available to researchers, scholars, and the public in accordance with copyright laws. Amendments include allowing films to be preserved in any format and changing the effective date from 7 to 17 years. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003, also known as Title II, reauthorizes and amends the National Film Preservation Foundation. It ensures the proper storage and accessibility of films in the National Film Registry, allowing preservation in any format and extending the effective date from 7 to 17 years. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 amends various sections of title 36, United States Code, related to the Board of Directors, Powers, Principal Office, and Authorization of Appropriations. Key changes include increasing the number of board members to 12, removing term limits, changing the jurisdiction in Powers section, and allowing the board to determine the principal office location. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 amends the United States Code by authorizing appropriations to the Library of Congress for film preservation. The Act limits administrative expenses and allows for private contributions to be matched by the corporation. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 amends the United States Code to support cooperative national film preservation and access initiatives approved by the corporation, the Librarian of Congress, and the National Film Preservation Board. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 authorizes appropriations up to $1,000,000 annually for film preservation activities such as repatriation, exhibition, production of educational materials, and addressing unfunded preservation needs. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 authorizes appropriations for film preservation activities from 2006 to 2013. The funds are to match private contributions and cannot be used for administrative expenses. The National Film Preservation Foundation Reauthorization Act of 2003 authorizes appropriations for film preservation activities from 2006 to 2013, with funds matching private contributions and excluding administrative expenses. Amended sections 151711 and 151712 are replaced with new language.
